key_insight: PoseBench provides a standardized benchmark showing that modern deep-learning docking and structure-prediction models can produce accurate protein–ligand poses in many cases but exhibit systematic failure modes and limited generalization to novel targets and chemotypes.
problem_solved: Addresses the lack of a rigorous, comparable benchmark for evaluating and diagnosing the real-world strengths and limitations of AI-based protein–ligand docking and structure-prediction methods.
method: Assembled PoseBench: a curated, diverse dataset of protein–ligand complexes with standardized evaluation metrics (e.g., RMSD-based success rates).
Systematically evaluated representative deep-learning docking and structure-prediction models under consistent protocols to compare accuracy, confidence calibration, and robustness.
Performed diagnostic analyses of failure modes and generalization (by target family and ligand chemistry) to identify specific gaps and limitations.
impact: Gives AI/ML practitioners a clear, reproducible benchmark and diagnostic framework to measure progress, prioritize improvements (e.g., generalization and uncertainty estimation), and make model choices for drug-discovery applications.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram of PoseBench: dataset curation → standardized metrics → evaluation workflow
Bar/box chart comparing model success rates at multiple RMSD thresholds (e.g., 2 Å, 5 Å)
Scatter plot of predicted confidence vs. actual pose error to show calibration and outliers
Heatmap/matrix of failure modes by protein family and ligand chemistry to highlight systematic weaknesses
paper_title: Assessing the potential of deep learning for protein–ligand docking
paper_authors: Alex Morehead, Nabin Giri, Jian Liu, Pawan Neupane, Jianlin Cheng
